tasks.title: Setup Next.js Project with Child-Friendly UI Framework
tasks.description: Initialize a Next.js application with responsive design, server-side rendering, and static generation. Set up the project structure with a focus on child-friendly UI components.
tasks.details:
1. Create a new Next.js project using `npx create-next-app@latest storyforge --typescript`
2. Set up project structure with directories for components, pages, styles, utils, and API routes
3. Configure Tailwind CSS for styling with a bright, colorful palette suitable for children
4. Create a theme configuration with large buttons, readable fonts, and child-friendly UI elements
5. Set up responsive design breakpoints for different device sizes
6. Install necessary dependencies: React, Next.js, Tailwind CSS, TypeScript
7. Configure ESLint and Prettier for code quality
8. Set up dyslexia-friendly font options
9. Create basic layout components with large, colorful interface elements
10. Implement accessibility features for young users
tasks.testStrategy:
1. Verify project builds without errors
2. Test responsive design on various screen sizes
3. Validate accessibility using automated tools (Lighthouse, axe)
4. Ensure UI components render correctly with child-friendly styling
5. Verify dyslexia-friendly font options work correctly

subtasks.testStrategy: Verify project builds without errors. Ensure all directories are properly created. Check that TypeScript configuration is working correctly. Validate ESLint and Prettier configurations.

Set up typography with readable, dyslexia-friendly font options. Define custom component styles for buttons, cards, and other UI elements with larger sizes and rounded corners.
subtasks.testStrategy: Verify Tailwind CSS is properly configured. Test that custom theme colors render correctly. Ensure dyslexia-friendly fonts are working. Check that UI components match the child-friendly design specifications.

subtasks.title: Responsive Design Implementation
subtasks.description: Set up responsive design breakpoints and layouts to ensure the application works well on various devices used by children.
subtasks.details: Configure responsive breakpoints in Tailwind for different device sizes (mobile, tablet, desktop). Create responsive layout components that adapt to screen sizes. Implement touch-friendly interfaces for mobile and tablet users. Ensure text and UI elements scale appropriately across devices.
subtasks.testStrategy: Test responsive layouts on various screen sizes and devices. Verify touch interactions work properly on mobile devices. Ensure content remains readable and accessible at all breakpoints. Use browser dev tools to simulate different device sizes.

subtasks.title: Accessibility Features for Young Users
subtasks.description: Implement accessibility features specifically designed for children of different ages and abilities.
subtasks.details: Add proper ARIA attributes to all interactive elements. Implement keyboard navigation for all features. Create high contrast mode option. Add text-to-speech capabilities for younger readers. Ensure color combinations meet WCAG standards. Implement focus indicators that are clear and engaging for children.
subtasks.testStrategy: Run automated accessibility tests using Lighthouse and axe. Test keyboard navigation throughout the application. Verify text-to-speech functionality works correctly. Test with screen readers to ensure compatibility. Conduct manual accessibility review.

subtasks.title: Basic Layout Components Creation
subtasks.description: Develop reusable layout components with child-friendly UI elements that will serve as the foundation for the application.
subtasks.details: Create a main Layout component with header, footer, and navigation. Develop child-friendly UI components including large buttons, colorful cards, and engaging icons. Implement a navigation system with visual cues appropriate for children. Create form components with simplified inputs and clear validation messages. Add animation components that enhance engagement without being distracting.
subtasks.testStrategy: Test all components in isolation using component testing tools. Verify components render correctly at all breakpoints. Test component interactions and state changes. Ensure animations work properly and don't cause performance issues. Validate accessibility of all components.

tasks.title: Implement SQLite Database Integration
tasks.description: Set up a lightweight SQLite database to store user data, stories, and other application content with appropriate schema design for the StoryForge platform.
tasks.details:
1. Install required packages: `npm install sqlite sqlite3 better-sqlite3`
2. Create database schema with the following tables:
   - Users (id, username, age_group, parent_email, created_at)
   - Stories (id, title, author_id, age_group, template_type, status, created_at, updated_at)
   - StorySegments (id, story_id, content, image_url, position, parent_segment_id)
   - Characters (id, story_id, name, attributes, image_url)
   - ParentalApprovals (id, story_id, approved, approval_date, parent_id)
3. Implement database connection utility
4. Create data access layer with CRUD operations for each entity
5. Implement data validation to ensure age-appropriate content
6. Set up database migrations for future updates
7. Implement connection pooling for performance
8. Add error handling and logging for database operations
tasks.testStrategy:
1. Unit test all CRUD operations
2. Test database schema with sample data
3. Verify data validation works correctly
4. Test error handling for database operations
5. Benchmark database performance with simulated load

subtasks.title: Implement Accessibility and Achievement Features

subtasks.title: Design and implement kid-friendly UI for AI Story Helper

Implement responsive UI components using React that work well on both desktop and mobile devices. Include colorful theme elements for each story direction (Adventure, Mystery, Fantasy). Ensure accessibility standards are met for young users.

subtasks.title: Implement content safety and deviation detection

subtasks.title: Integrate AI Story Helper with database and user profiles

subtasks.testStrategy: Test database operations for prompt storage and retrieval. Verify age-based access controls work correctly. Test API endpoints with various input scenarios. Verify user preferences are correctly saved and applied.

tasks.title: Fine-tune LLM for Children's Story Generation
tasks.description: Fine-tune a language model specifically for children's story generation using curated datasets, ensuring age-appropriate, engaging content for different age groups (7-10, 11-16).
tasks.details:
1. Set up fine-tuning environment:
   - Install necessary libraries: transformers, datasets, accelerate, torch
   - Configure GPU acceleration if available
   - Set up experiment tracking with Weights & Biases or TensorBoard

2. Collect and prepare age-appropriate datasets:
   - Create a `datasets` folder with the following structure:
     ```
     datasets/
     ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ age_7_10/
     ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ stories/
     ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ templates/
     ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ age_11_16/
     ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ stories/
     ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ templates/
     ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ safety_filters/
     ```
   - Curate children's literature from public domain sources (Project Gutenberg, Storynory)
   - Collect age-appropriate story templates for different genres
   - Create safety-filtered content guidelines and examples

3. Preprocess training data:
   - Clean and normalize text (remove irrelevant metadata, standardize formatting)
   - Split stories into appropriate training chunks
   - Create prompt-completion pairs for fine-tuning
   - Apply content safety filtering to ensure child-appropriate material
   - Create validation sets for quality assessment

4. Select base model for fine-tuning:
   - Choose a smaller model compatible with Ollama (Phi-3, Mistral 7B, or Llama 3 8B)
   - Evaluate base model performance on story generation tasks
   - Configure model parameters for fine-tuning (learning rate, epochs)

5. Implement fine-tuning pipeline:
   - Set up LoRA (Low-Rank Adaptation) or QLoRA for efficient fine-tuning
   - Configure training parameters (batch size, gradient accumulation)
   - Implement early stopping based on validation performance
   - Set up checkpointing to save model progress

6. Train model with age-specific datasets:
   - Fine-tune separate model variants for each age group (7-10, 11-16)
   - Monitor training metrics (loss, perplexity)
   - Evaluate generation quality periodically during training
   - Apply content safety reinforcement during training

7. Evaluate fine-tuned models:
   - Create evaluation prompts specific to children's stories
   - Assess readability scores for different age groups
   - Evaluate content safety and appropriateness
   - Compare with base model performance

8. Export and integrate with Ollama:
   - Convert fine-tuned models to GGUF format for Ollama compatibility
   - Create Modelfile with appropriate parameters and system prompts
   - Test integration with the existing Ollama setup
   - Document model capabilities and limitations

9. Create API integration:
   - Extend the existing Ollama integration to use the fine-tuned models
   - Implement model selection based on age group
   - Add specialized prompt templates for the fine-tuned models
   - Implement fallback mechanisms if fine-tuned model fails

10. Document the fine-tuning process:
    - Create detailed documentation of the dataset curation process
    - Document model training parameters and results
    - Provide guidelines for future model updates and improvements
tasks.testStrategy:
1. Evaluate base model vs. fine-tuned model performance:
   - Compare perplexity and loss metrics on held-out validation data
   - Conduct human evaluation of story quality with educators or children's literature experts
   - Measure improvements in age-appropriateness and engagement

2. Test content safety and appropriateness:
   - Create a test suite of prompts designed to probe safety boundaries
   - Verify the model rejects inappropriate content generation
   - Test with edge cases that might produce unsafe content
   - Ensure content aligns with educational standards for target age groups

3. Benchmark generation performance:
   - Measure inference speed on target hardware
   - Test memory usage during generation
   - Evaluate token generation throughput
   - Compare performance with original Ollama model

4. Conduct age-appropriateness testing:
   - Create a rubric for evaluating age-appropriateness of generated content
   - Test with prompts targeting different reading levels
   - Verify vocabulary and concept complexity matches target age groups
   - Assess narrative structure appropriateness for different ages

5. Integration testing with StoryForge platform:
   - Test API integration with the Next.js application
   - Verify proper model selection based on user age group
   - Test error handling and fallback mechanisms
   - Measure end-to-end latency for story generation

6. Conduct A/B testing with users:
   - Compare user engagement with base model vs. fine-tuned model stories
   - Collect feedback on story quality and relevance
   - Measure completion rates for stories from different models
   - Analyze user preferences between models

7. Validate against content guidelines:
   - Check compliance with COPPA and other children's content regulations
   - Verify absence of problematic themes or content
   - Test with diverse prompts to ensure consistent safety
   - Document any limitations or edge cases discovered
